TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . She was represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON .
In DATE the applicant ’s daughter , a university student , was raped and murdered .

On DATE ORG convicted several persons of criminal offences committed in the above context . Prison terms of CARDINAL were imposed . On DATE ORG of GPE upheld the firstinstance judgment . The applicant had joined the criminal proceedings with a claim for damages .
On DATE ORG of the NORP and GPE , upon a complaint lodged by ORG , quashed the decisions convicting the persons charged . The case was sent back to ORG for a fresh examination .

Subsequently the case was dealt with by courts at CARDINAL levels of jurisdiction . In DATE the first - instance court decided that the charges against one of the accused would be dealt with in a separate set of proceedings . That set of proceedings was stayed as experts concluded that the accused suffered from a mental disorder ( for further details relating to the period up to DATE see Andrášik and Others v. GPE ( dec . ) , nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL , PERSON , DATE , CARDINAL , DATE , ORG CARDINAL-IX ) .

On DATE ORG in GPE delivered a judgment convicting the accused persons ( with the exception of the one in respect of whom the proceedings had been stayed ) . The accused and the public prosecutor appealed . On DATE the file was submitted to ORG .
DATE and DATE the accused made CARDINAL submissions with a view to completing the reasons for their appeal .
On DATE ORG had to adjourn the case as the newly appointed counsel of one of the accused had not appeared .
The next hearing was scheduled for DATE . It was adjourned as the presiding judge was ill .
On DATE ORG heard the final speeches .
On DATE ORG modified the first - instance judgment in that it imposed more severe sentences on CARDINAL of the convicted persons .

On DATE and on DATE the applicant filed a complaint with ORG . She alleged a violation of her rights under LAW to a hearing within a reasonable time and LAW for her private life in the context of the criminal proceedings concerning the offences committed against her daughter which she had joined with a claim for damages .

On DATE ORG declared admissible the complaint about the length of the proceedings . It further rejected the complaint under LAW . It admitted that there could be an interference with the applicant ’s right to respect for her private and family life as a result of the excessive length of the proceedings . However , LAW was a lex specialis

In a judgment of DATE ORG found that both ORG in GPE and ORG had violated the applicant ’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time in the above criminal proceedings . It ordered ORG to pay CARDINAL NORP korunas ( SKK ) to the applicant as just satisfaction . That sum was payable within DATE from the final effect of the judgment . It also ordered ORG to reimburse the applicant ’s costs of legal representation in the constitutional proceedings within DATE . Finally , ORG ordered ORG to proceed with the case without any further delay .

ORG had jurisdiction to examine the length of the proceedings in issue as from DATE . It admitted that the case had been complex to a certain extent , in particular because the offences in issue had been committed DATE . The applicant by her conduct had not contributed to the length of the proceedings . Their overall length was in itself incompatible with the applicant ’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time . As regards the conduct of ORG in particular , it had remained inactive for DATE without any justification . ORG also recalled that in its finding of CARDINAL DATE given in proceedings initiated by the accused persons it had ordered ORG to deal with the case without delay . There had been unjustified delays also as regards the conduct of ORG in the separate set of proceedings concerning CARDINAL of the accused persons .

As regards the proceedings before ORG , ORG noted , in particular , that the first hearing had been scheduled after DATE . Such a period was excessive in view of the overall length of the proceedings . ORG held that the finding of a violation in respect of the proceedings before ORG , together with its order that ORG should avoid further delays in the proceedings , constituted in itself appropriate satisfaction as regards the appeal proceedings .
